Barbara Boxer but still significantly lower than her suggested range.

Moreover, the text explains that the administrative burden for private plans varies greatly depending on factors such as the size of the plan and whether it's employer-based or individual. The variations in these data points also contribute to the conflicting nature of Sen. Boxer's claim.

claim: SaysLoretta Lynch’s nomination "has been now sitting there longer than the previous seven attorney general nominees combined."
justification: The label "True" is appropriate for this claim because the evidence presented clearly demonstrates that Loretta Lynch's nomination has indeed been sitting in the Senate longer than the previous seven attorney general nominees combined. The article provides a table listing the confirmation timelines of each of the previous seven attorneys general, totaling 119 days. It then goes on to explain that as of April 17, 2015 (the day of Obama's comment), Lynch had waited for 155 days since her nomination was received in the Senate, and by the article's publication date, she had waited for 158 days. This is clearly longer than the combined waiting time of the previous seven nominees. Therefore, the claim "Says Loretta Lynch’s nomination 'has been now sitting there longer than the previous seven attorney general nominees combined'" can be deemed true based on the evidence presented.

claim: Says Hillary Clinton’s approval rating went from 70 percent to 52 percent in 18 months.
justification:
The claim that "Says Hillary Clinton’s approval rating went from 70 percent to 52 percent in 18 months" is labeled as conflicting because the information presented in the evidence demonstrates inconsistencies regarding Clinton's approval ratings over time. While Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus stated that Clinton's approval rating had dropped by 18 points (from 70% to 52%) during an 18-month period, the article reveals conflicting figures from various poll sources.

   The evidence mentions a Bloomberg National Poll from December 2012 which found Clinton's net favorable rating at just 52%, while other polls around that time put her approval rating as high as 67%. It also indicates that the Huffington Post Pollster, which aggregates and averages most credible polls, had Clinton’s favorability rating at 58.2% on Dec. 9, 2012. Furthermore, the article suggests that while a drop in favorability was observed in Clinton's approval ratings from December 2012 to June 2014, it was not as drastic as suggested by Priebus (a drop of 18 points versus 5 points according to the data presented).

   Thus, the label "Conflicting" is appropriate for this claim because there are conflicting and inconsistent figures presented in the evidence regarding Clinton's approval rating over the specified time period.

claim: Says Donald Trump’s tax plan gives the wealthy and corporations "more than the Bush tax cuts by at least a factor of two."
justification: The claim that Donald Trump's tax plan gives the wealthy and corporations "more than the Bush tax cuts by at least a factor of two" can be justified as true based on the evidence provided in the article. According to the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, the Bush tax cuts increased the after-tax income of the top 1% between 5.3% and 6.7%, which amounts to about 0.66% of GDP. On the other hand, Trump's tax plan would increase the after-tax incomes of the wealthy between 10.2% to 19.9%, according to the Tax Foundation, and deliver a tax cut equivalent to about 1.32% of GDP. Therefore, it can be seen that the top 1% under Trump's tax plan would receive a tax break equivalent to about twice as much as they did under the Bush tax cuts, supporting the claim made in the article. Furthermore, the article provides additional details on key provisions of Trump's tax plan that contribute to the increased benefits for the wealthy, such as reducing the top marginal income tax rate and corporate income tax rate, and not taking into account one additional proposal (eliminating the carried interest tax break) could potentially increase the gains for the top 1%. Thus, it can be concluded that Clinton's statement in the debate is accurate based on the evidence presented.

claim: "Just two weeks ago, Congressman Hurd quit his post on the House Committee on Small Business saying that he was unable to find the time to serve."
justification: The claim "Just two weeks ago, Congressman Hurd quit his post on the House Committee on Small Business saying that he was unable to find the time to serve" is labeled as conflicting because the supporting article text provides evidence indicating that the reasons for Hurd's resignation from the committee were different than what was initially stated by Pete Gallego. According to the Congressional Record, Hurd requested to resign from the House Committee on Small Business in a letter dated March 16, 2015, and cited his other existing committee assignments as the reason for his decision. Furthermore, there is no evidence provided that Hurd resigned two weeks prior to the article's publication date (April 7, 2015). Instead, it appears from the text that Hurd had already been removed from the small business committee at least a month before Gallego made his claim in an April 2, 2015 email blast. Therefore, the conflicting label is appropriate as the evidence provided contradicts the initial claim made by Gallego regarding the timing and reasons for Congressman Hurd's resignation from the House Committee on Small Business.

claim: The "working tax cut" created "over 40,000 new jobs in just the last four years."
justification:
The claim that "The 'working tax cut' created over 40,000 new jobs in just the last four years" is labeled as False because the evidence presented shows that the data used by Associated Industries of Florida (AIF) to support their claim does not accurately reflect the growth of insurance industry jobs.

The discrepancy lies in how the job numbers are calculated. According to the Bureau of Economic Analysis and the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which provide the data for the state reports referenced by AIF, there was a net loss of insurance industry jobs between 2007 and 2010. This contradicts AIF's claim that over 40,000 new jobs were created in the last four years.

Furthermore, it is suggested that the apparent growth in jobs may be due to a change in how the job numbers are calculated, not as a result of the "working tax cut." The state's count for insurance jobs in 2007 excluded proprietors and general partners, but the 2010 number included them. An apples-to-apples comparison of job growth shows that the state actually lost insurance industry jobs between 2007 and 2010 when comparing the same set of data.

Therefore, based on the evidence provided, it cannot be accurately claimed that the "working tax cut" created over 40,000 new jobs in just the last four years.

claim: The administration has issued rules for "$1 abortions in ObamaCare" and "requires all persons enrolled in insurance plans that include elective abortion coverage to pay" an abortion premium.
justification:
The claim that "The administration has issued rules for '$1 abortions in ObamaCare' and 'requires all persons enrolled in insurance plans that include elective abortion coverage to pay' an abortion premium" can be labeled as False according to the evidence provided. This is due to several reasons:

1. The evidence explains that the "$1 abortions" claim is based on the Obama administration setting a minimum amount of $1 per enrollee, per month for insurers offering plans that include abortion coverage. However, this amount is for filling the account where the money for abortion services will be kept, not for the cost of an abortion itself.

2. The evidence also makes clear that this rule applies only to insurers offering such coverage and does not mandate all persons enrolled in insurance plans to pay a separate premium for abortion. Instead, it states that federal dollars and most of the premiums paid by the plan's beneficiaries will go into the non-abortion account, with a fraction sent to the abortion account.

3. Lastly, the evidence points out that even if you have the opportunity to buy abortion coverage on the exchanges, it won't be forced upon anyone and tax dollars sent to those plans through federal subsidies will be placed in accounts walled off from accounts used to pay for abortion services. This means that anyone purchasing a plan with abortion coverage will be doing so by choice and paying for it personally.

In summary, the evidence provided demonstrates that the claim is not accurate as it has misrepresented the $1 amount as related to the cost of an abortion and has incorrectly stated that all persons enrolled in insurance plans are required to pay a separate premium for abortion coverage.

claim: "In last week’s debate, Bernie questioned Hillary’s commitment to fighting climate change because a whopping 0.2 percent of the money given to our campaign has come from employees of oil and gas companies. Not even 2 percent, mind you: 0.2 percent."
justification:
The claim "In last week’s debate, Bernie questioned Hillary’s commitment to fighting climate change because a whopping 0.2 percent of the money given to our campaign has come from employees of oil and gas companies" is indeed true, as supported by the provided evidence.

The article presents data from the Center for Responsive Politics that verifies Clinton's campaign received $307,561 from people employed by the oil and gas industry, which amounts to 0.17 percent of the total amount raised ($180 million). This is a slight discrepancy from what Mook stated in the debate (0.2 percent), but it still falls well within the range suggested by Sanders during the debate.

Furthermore, the article also acknowledges that while Mook focused solely on employee donations, other analyses by Greenpeace and The Huffington Post have pointed out that Clinton's campaign has received additional donations from lobbyists with ties to oil and gas interests. However, these lobbyist-derived donations are not reported as coming from employees of the oil and gas industry, and thus were not included in the total calculated by the article.

Despite this potential oversight, the overall statement remains accurate based on the direct evidence presented.

claim: "A report just came out that if we continue with President Obama's policies, we're looking at over 9 percent unemployment next year in the fourth quarter."
justification: The claim "A report just came out that if we continue with President Obama's policies, we're looking at over 9 percent unemployment next year in the fourth quarter" can be labeled as False because the report referred to by Rep. Michele Bachmann was not based on continuing "President Obama’s policies." Instead, it was a projection made by the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) about what would happen if current laws are left unchanged, which is not what President Obama advocates. The CBO's projection of 9.1% unemployment in the fourth quarter next year is based on the scenario where there is no resolution to the fiscal cliff, resulting in steep automatic spending cuts and the expiration of major tax cuts, neither of which are part of President Obama's policies. In fact, the CBO projects that if lawmakers and the president work out a deal that keeps the tax cuts and avoids automatic spending cuts, among other things, unemployment would drop to 8%. Therefore, the claim that we will see over 9% unemployment next year due to continuing President Obama's policies is not supported by the evidence.

claim: “Melania dug up the WH Rose Garden, removing roses from every First Lady since 1913.”
justification: The label "False" is appropriate because the claim that Melania Trump dug up the White House Rose Garden and removed roses from every First Lady since 1913 is unsubstantiated by the provided evidence. The article explains that while renovations were made to the garden, these changes were done in a manner consistent with the spirit of the garden's original design from 1962. Furthermore, the article mentions various roses that have been grown in the garden over time, and even though some existing plants may have been removed or replaced during renovations, there is no mention of an extensive removal of roses dating back to 1913. Therefore, the claim made in the original statement lacks credibility as it contradicts the information provided in the article.

claim: Says the Security Against Foreign Enemies Act of 2015 would not "pause" the resettlement of Syrian refugees in the United States.
justification:
The label "Conflicting" is appropriate because the claim made by U.S. Rep Annie Kuster that the Security Against Foreign Enemies Act of 2015 would not "pause" the resettlement of Syrian refugees in the United States, is contradictory to the evidence presented. While Kuster argues that the bill does not pause the program, the text of the bill and statements from the White House, U.S. Attorney General Loretta Lynch, FBI Director James Comey, and other lawmakers suggest otherwise.

   The bill, as explained in the article, adds layers of certification beyond what’s already on the books requiring that refugees are safe before entering the United States. This additional process is likely to cause delays, which could effectively pause or slow down the resettlement program for Syrian refugees. Furthermore, supporters of the bill, such as House Republicans, have explicitly stated that the bill would require a "pause" in admitting Syrian and Iraqi refugees while a new vetting process was established.

   However, it is worth noting that Kuster and 46 other House Democrats who supported the bill interpreted it as not hurting the refugee process significantly, suggesting that they believe the additional certifications could be put into place without many problems. This interpretation contradicts the implications of the bill as described in the evidence provided, which suggests that the delays caused by these additional checks could indeed pause or slow down the resettlement program.

   Therefore, while Kuster's statement may not have been intentionally misleading, it is conflicting based on the information presented in the article.

claim: Says Ronald Reagan "was behind in the polls in 1980 going into the debate with Jimmy Carter and then turned around 10 days later and won 40 states."
justification: Justification: The claim "Says Ronald Reagan 'was behind in the polls in 1980 going into the debate with Jimmy Carter and then turned around 10 days later and won 40 states'" is labeled as conflicting because the evidence provided shows that while it's true that Ronald Reagan won 40 states after the debate, it's not accurate to state that he was definitively behind in the polls going into the debate. The evidence demonstrates that various polls leading up to the debate had both candidates within the margin of error, making it impossible to conclusively determine which candidate was ahead. Therefore, the claim presents an oversimplified and potentially misleading interpretation of historical events.

claim: For 21 countries in Sub-Saharan Africa, "we simply do not have data to say anything about trends in poverty."
justification: Justification: The claim "For 21 countries in Sub-Saharan Africa, 'we simply do not have data to say anything about trends in poverty'" is accurate because the evidence provided clearly demonstrates that there are indeed 21 countries in this region for which there is insufficient data to track trends in poverty. The economist Morten Jerven contends that these countries lack the necessary starting and end points to measure trends due to inconsistent or limited data points, as highlighted by the World Bank's own report. This claim is further substantiated when Andrew Dabalen, a lead economist at the World Bank, acknowledges that 21 countries do not have at least two comparable surveys since 1990, making it impossible to accurately say anything about trends in poverty. Moreover, alternative methods for deriving missing data points are mentioned but acknowledged to be imperfect and potentially misleading, further supporting Jerven's claim of insufficient data. Thus, the evidence provided sufficiently supports the label "True" for this claim.

claim: Texas this fiscal year will "have more money in reserve than the other 49 states combined."
justification: The label "False" is appropriate because, according to the evidence presented, Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick claimed that Texas would end its fiscal year 2015 with more money in its rainy day fund than all other 49 states combined. However, data from the National Association of State Budget Officers (NASBO) report shows that while Texas was projected to have $8 billion in its rainy day fund by the end of fiscal 2015, combined reserves for all the other states were expected to be around $34 billion. This indicates that the sum total of reserves in California, New York, Ohio, Massachusetts, Florida, and Indiana alone is greater than Texas’ reserves, making it untrue that Texas would have more money in reserve than the other 49 states combined. This contradicts Patrick's claim made on KLBJ AM radio station.

claim: A poll conducted in Egypt revealed that 80 percent of Egyptians oppose receiving foreign aid from the United States.
justification: The label "True" for the claim "A poll conducted in Egypt revealed that 80 percent of Egyptians oppose receiving foreign aid from the United States" is appropriate because the provided evidence reveals that the source (Barry Hinckley) referenced a specific poll conducted in Egypt between January 31 and February 7, 2012. The evidence states that this survey of 1,000 Egyptians found that 82 percent opposed U.S. aid, with a margin of error of plus or minus 3.4 percentage points. This poll clearly demonstrates that the majority (82%) of Egyptians surveyed oppose receiving foreign aid from the United States, which aligns with the claim being made. The additional evidence also confirms similar results in a separate study conducted by the Pew Research Center. Therefore, it can be reasonably concluded that the claim is indeed true based on the provided evidence.

claim: Says Harvard scientists say the coronavirus is “spreading so fast that it will infect 70% of humanity this year.”
justification: The claim states that Harvard scientists predict the coronavirus will infect 70% of humanity this year. However, the evidence shows that while a Harvard epidemiologist Mark Lipsitch did make such a projection during an interview, his statement was characterized as "a projection" and not a definitive prediction. Moreover, the text explicitly states that it is uncertain whether this estimate will hold true as the situation unfolds. Additionally, the evidence indicates that other estimates from different sources vary slightly but share similar proportions (such as 60% by The Guardian and 2/3rds by Bloomberg). Therefore, the claim can be seen as an overgeneralization or misinterpretation of these expert opinions, making it conflicting with the actual statements made.

claim: Thirty-eight states -- Georgia not included -- have appointed, rather than elected, state school superintendents.
justification: The claim that "Thirty-eight states -- Georgia not included -- have appointed, rather than elected, state school superintendents" is true according to the provided evidence. This is because the article clearly states that out of the 37 states with appointed superintendents and 13 states with elected superintendents, Georgia is one of the states with an elected superintendent. Furthermore, the information in the article comes from credible sources such as the Council of Chief State School Officers and the Education Commission of the States, who keep data on these matters. The fact that the number of states with appointed superintendents is significantly higher than those with elected ones supports the claim made in the article. Therefore, the label "True" is appropriate for this claim based on the evidence provided.

claim: Says U.S. Rep. Tammy Baldwin, a candidate for Senate, supports raising taxes "by $858 billion."
justification:
The claim "Says U.S. Rep. Tammy Baldwin, a candidate for Senate, supports raising taxes 'by $858 billion'" is labeled as Conflicting due to the following reasons:

1. While it is true that Baldwin voted against a bill that extended the Bush-era tax cuts, the ad's assertion that she supports raising taxes by $858 billion oversimplifies the issue. The bill in question not only extended the Bush-era tax cuts but also included other measures such as a new payroll tax cut and extended unemployment benefits.

2. The ad fails to acknowledge that Baldwin did vote for an alternative bill that would have extended the Bush tax cuts permanently for families earning less than $250,000, which would have had a different fiscal impact compared to the original bill she voted against.

3. The claim also does not consider the potential outcome if Baldwin's side had defeated the initial bill and another bill was introduced, as suggested by Baldwin campaign spokesman Phil Walzak.

In summary, the claim is conflicting because it oversimplifies the situation by only focusing on one vote without considering the other competing proposals, their fiscal impacts, and potential future legislative actions.

claim: “VA Democrats authorized for early release over 4,000 inmates, 60% of which are incarcerated for violent offenses.”
justification:
The label "True" is appropriate because the claim made in the statement, that Democrats authorized the early release of over 4,000 inmates where 60% are incarcerated for violent offenses, can be substantiated by the facts presented in the article.

The evidence shows that Del. Nick Freitas' statements were based on a budget amendment approved by the Democratic-led General Assembly, at the request of Governor Ralph Northam. This amendment allowed for the Department of Corrections to release inmates with less than a year left on their sentences due to concerns about the spread of COVID-19 in state prisons.

The article further clarifies that out of the 4,618 inmates who will enter the last year of their sentences by April 30, 2021, 2,761 (or 62%) are legally classified as violent offenders. This aligns with the claim that 60% of those authorized for early release are incarcerated for violent offenses.

Therefore, it can be concluded that the claim made in the statement is supported by the evidence provided and is, therefore, true.

claim: "Today, there are more Hoosiers going to work than ever before in the 200-year history of the great state of Indiana."
justification:
The claim made by Indiana Governor Mike Pence about the number of Hoosiers going to work today being a historical high in the 200-year history of the state is labeled as "Conflicting." This is because the evidence demonstrates that while more people are indeed employed today compared to any point in the past, this increase does not necessarily reflect a stronger economy. The increase is largely due to population growth rather than job market improvement.

The article reveals that although there were 3.07 million Hoosiers working in May 2016, which is more than at any other time in history, this figure doesn't tell the whole story. A more meaningful comparison would be the percentage of Indiana residents who are employed, rather than just the raw number.

According to Census Bureau data, in 2015 there were about 6.48 million people living in Indiana. So only 47.3% of Indiana's population was working in 2016. However, in May 2000, when the raw number of Hoosiers employed reached its previous high, 49.7% of Indiana's then-population of 6.08 million people were working. This means a larger percentage of Indiana residents were employed in 2000 than in 2016.

Furthermore, the article explains that focusing on the total number of people employed can be misleading and may not accurately reflect the health of the job market. The unemployment rate, which takes into account only those actively looking for a job, is a more reliable indicator of the job market's strength. Indiana's current 5% unemployment rate is considered good but is far from a historical low.

In conclusion, while more Hoosiers are going to work today than at any other point in history, this increase does not necessarily indicate a stronger economy. The raw number of people employed is less significant than the percentage of Indiana's population that is working, and unemployment rates provide a better measure of job market strength. Therefore, Pence's assertion that more Hoosiers are going to work today than ever before may be technically accurate but is ultimately misleading.

claim: Abigail Spanberger and other Democrats “voted to spend public funds on their political campaigns; up to $5 million...”
justification: Justification: The label "Conflicting" is appropriate because while the claim states that Abigail Spanberger voted to spend public funds on her political campaigns up to $5 million, the evidence provided shows that this is not an accurate representation of the situation. The For the People Act of 2019, which Spanberger co-sponsored and voted for, provides a 6-to-1 match for small-dollar donations ($200 or less) and creates a pilot program for $25 vouchers for eligible voters to give to their favored candidates. However, participation in this public financing system is optional, and it would only be available if a candidate agrees not to accept any single contribution of more than $200, and any aggregate donations from an individual or PAC of more than $1,000. Therefore, while Spanberger did vote for legislation that could potentially provide funding for political campaigns, the claim oversimplifies the conditions under which this funding would be available, making it conflicting with the truth.

claim: Says Mitt Romney "paid only 14 percent in taxes — probably less than you."
justification:
The label "Conflicting" is appropriate because while the claim made in the ad that Mitt Romney's tax rate is lower than many Americans is not entirely accurate when considering income taxes alone, it becomes accurate when taking into account both income and payroll taxes.

Income taxes alone, Romney's effective tax rate of 13.9% is higher than the average tax rates for the bottom four fifths of earners, but lower than those in the second-highest fifth (8.2%) and significantly lower than the highest fifth (17.3%). However, when adding payroll taxes, it can be reasonably assumed that Romney's effective tax rate would exceed 14%, making the claim accurate for a majority of American taxpayers.

Furthermore, the evidence provided shows that a significant share of the middle group (middle fifth) and the top two ranges (second-highest fifth and highest fifth) most likely did pay a higher effective tax rate than Romney's 14%, which validates the Obama ad's claim when considering both income and payroll taxes.

In conclusion, while there is some inaccuracy in the claim when only considering income taxes, the claim becomes accurate when taking into account both income and payroll taxes, making it a conflicting statement overall.

claim: "Amendment 2 will put almost 2,000 pot shops in Florida ... more pot shops than Walmart and Walgreens combined."
justification:
The claim that "Amendment 2 will put almost 2,000 pot shops in Florida ... more pot shops than Walmart and Walgreens combined" is labeled as conflicting because the article presents conflicting information about the potential number of marijuana dispensaries if Amendment 2 passes.

On one hand, the opponents of Amendment 2 claim that there will be approximately 2,000 dispensaries in Florida, a number that surpasses the combined total of Walmart and Walgreens stores in the state. On the other hand, the proponents of Amendment 2 acknowledge this estimate but also mention that the actual number could be significantly less or more depending on regulations set by the Legislature and the Florida Health Department.

Therefore, it is unclear whether Amendment 2 would result in the opening of almost 2,000 marijuana dispensaries across Florida, making the claim conflicting. The article presents both sides of the argument but does not provide a definitive answer, leaving the claim open to interpretation and potential misinformation.

claim: "Women in Oregon are paid 79 cents for every dollar paid to men. If the wage gap was eliminated, a working woman in Oregon would have enough money for 2,877 gallons of gas, 72 more weeks of food for her family or nearly 12 more months of rent."
justification:
The label "True" is appropriate because the evidence presented directly supports the claim made about women's earnings in Oregon compared to men's. The evidence states that the National Partnership For Women & Families analyzed data from the U.S. Census Bureau, which showed that full-time working women in Oregon earned $37,381 a year, while their male counterparts earned $47,402 - a difference of $10,021 or 79 cents for every dollar men earned. This data aligns with the claim that women are paid 79 cents for every dollar men earn in Oregon, thus validating its truthfulness.

Additionally, the evidence provides supporting examples of how closing the wage gap would impact a woman's life by giving her enough money for 2,877 gallons of gas, 72 more weeks of food for her family, or nearly 12 more months of rent. While there are slight discrepancies in the exact quantities due to factors such as fluctuations in gas prices and rounding of figures, these differences do not negate the overall validity of the claim since they are within reasonable margins of error.

Therefore, based on this evidence, it can be concluded that the claim is "True."

claim: Says combined inflation and unemployment rates in October 2011 were the highest since Ronald Reagan succeeded Jimmy Carter.
justification:
The claim "Says combined inflation and unemployment rates in October 2011 were the highest since Ronald Reagan succeeded Jimmy Carter" is labeled as False because the provided evidence clearly demonstrates that the misery index (the combination of inflation and unemployment rates) for October 2011 was lower than any month during Ronald Reagan's presidency, including his first year in office.

   The article states that in October 2011, the misery index was 12.43 based on an 8.9% unemployment rate and a 3.53% inflation rate. This number is significantly lower than the highest misery index during Ronald Reagan's presidency, which was 21.98 in June 1980 (Carter's last year as president). Furthermore, the article presents data showing that the misery index was higher at various points throughout Reagan's first three years in office than it was in October 2011. Therefore, it is clear that the claim made by the individual in question is incorrect.

claim: "In 45 out of 50 states, on average men are seeing their premiums double, going up 99 percent. Women up 62 percent."
justification:
The claim that "In 45 out of 50 states, on average men are seeing their premiums double, going up 99 percent. Women up 62 percent" can be labeled as conflicting because the evidence provided indicates that the numbers presented by Hannity are not accurate or complete.

The evidence shows that Hannity's claim is based on a study by the Manhattan Institute for Policy Research, which focused on insurance rates in the online marketplaces, accounting for less than 10 percent of the total private insurance market. Moreover, the study did not factor in federal government subsidies, which will reduce many people’s out-of-pocket expenses and partially offset higher premiums.

Furthermore, Hannity's claim lumps together people who purchase insurance on their own with people who receive it through their employer, which is an error since the study specifically addressed the individual market. Therefore, the claim is conflicting as it presents data that does not represent the entirety of the insured population and omits crucial factors such as federal subsidies.

claim: "Pregnant women who stand for five to six hours at a time increase their risk of pre-term pregnancy by 80 percent."
justification:
The claim "Pregnant women who stand for five to six hours at a time increase their risk of pre-term pregnancy by 80 percent" has been labeled as conflicting based on the evidence provided in the article. The supporting evidence demonstrates that there is disagreement and contradiction among experts regarding the specific risk percentage associated with prolonged standing during pregnancy and pre-term birth.

The article mentions several studies, including one from 1995, which found a 20% increase in the likelihood of premature delivery for women who stood at work for five hours per day, significantly lower than the 80% claim made in the original statement. Another study cited found an increased risk of preterm birth by 26%, which is also substantially lower than the 80%.

Moreover, the article discusses a 2000 review in the journal Obstetrics and Gynecology that combined results from multiple studies on prolonged standing and pre-term birth. This review found that prolonged standing increased the risk by 26%, which is much lower than the 80% claim made in the original statement.

The article also mentions that some more recent studies have found no significant risk or a significantly smaller risk for premature delivery among women who stand for more than six hours per day, further contradicting the claim made in the original statement.

In summary, the evidence provided shows that various experts disagree on the specific risk percentage associated with prolonged standing during pregnancy and pre-term birth, making the claim conflicting.

claim: Says Hillary Clinton called Barack Obama "naive" for saying he was would "sit down and talk to the Iranians" during the 2008 Democratic primary.
justification:
The label "Conflicting" is appropriate because the claim states that Hillary Clinton called Barack Obama "naive" for saying he would sit down and talk to the Iranians during the 2008 Democratic primary, while the evidence shows that this characterization oversimplifies Clinton's stance on the matter.

   While it is true that Clinton did express concern about meeting with Iranian leaders within the first year of becoming president without any preconditions, she also advocated for a diplomatic approach to adversaries and acknowledged the importance of dialogue. However, her position was more cautious than Obama's in this specific context, as she planned to send envoys rather than meet herself without preconditions.

   Furthermore, Sanders' statement that Clinton was wrong and Obama was right in their approach to Iran is also an oversimplification of the nuanced positions held by both candidates during the 2008 Democratic primary. The evidence shows that their differences were not as straightforward as the claim suggests, and both candidates had distinct but valid arguments for their diplomatic strategies towards Iran.

   Therefore, the claim presents a conflicting picture of the actual events, as it omits key details and distorts Clinton's position on the matter to imply she was dismissive of diplomacy with Iran, which is not fully supported by the evidence provided.

claim: "When adjusted for inflation, (Texas) per-student spending has remained relatively flat over the past 16 years. Despite that trend, Texas schools in 2017 will receive $381 less per student than they did in 2003."
justification:
The claim that "When adjusted for inflation, (Texas) per-student spending has remained relatively flat over the past 16 years. Despite that trend, Texas schools in 2017 will receive $381 less per student than they did in 2003" is labeled as conflicting because, according to the provided evidence, both the Center for Public Policy Priorities report and the Legislative Budget Board analysis contradict each other regarding the real change in per-student spending when adjusted for inflation.

While the report suggests that Texas schools will receive $381 less per student in 2017 than they did in 2003, the Legislative Budget Board analysis indicates a slight increase in per-student spending ($10,111 in 2017 versus $10,078 in 2003). The discrepancy arises from the different inflation indices used for adjusting the data: the report uses the Implicit Price Deflator for state/local government from the Bureau of Economic Analysis, while the board uniformly employs the Consumer Price Index (CPI) to analyze education spending. There is no consensus about using the IPD rather than CPI when analyzing education spending, as both methods have their advantages and disadvantages in capturing cost increases for governments.

Therefore, it is conflicting to claim that per-student spending has remained relatively flat over the past 16 years while simultaneously arguing that schools will receive $381 less per student in 2017 than they did in 2003, as both claims cannot be true based on the available evidence.

claim: Says that 500,000 federal workers -- one-fourth of the federal workforce -- make more than $100,000 a year.
justification: The claim "Says that 500,000 federal workers -- one-fourth of the federal workforce -- make more than $100,000 a year" can be labeled as True because the article provides clear evidence supporting this statement. The evidence indicates that at the time for which data was available (June), there were 459,016 federal workers who made at least $100,000 in average base salary each year, which is close to the number Romney claimed. Although Romney stated that one-fourth of federal workers make more than $100,000 a year, he meant to say nearly a quarter (approximately 22%), as confirmed by his campaign spokesman. Therefore, it can be concluded that the claim is substantiated and accurate, even if not perfectly precise.

claim: "We saw the prison population expand and vacancy rates for correctional officers go from 2.9% to 15.2%" over the last eight years.
justification:
The claim that "We saw the prison population expand and vacancy rates for correctional officers go from 2.9% to 15.2%" over the last eight years is true because the provided evidence demonstrates an increase in both metrics during the stated time frame.

First, it is shown that the prison population grew from 2011 (21,941) to 2018 (23,675), a 7.9% increase over eight years, which aligns with the claim of an expansion in the prison population.

Second, it is revealed that correctional officer vacancy rates have also increased significantly from 2011 (2.87%) to 2019 (15.27%). The evidence shows a steady increase in vacancies except for a dip in 2017, with the rate more than quadrupling over eight years, supporting the claim that vacancy rates went from 2.9% to 15.2%.

Therefore, based on the provided evidence, the label "True" is appropriate as the prison population did expand, and correctional officer vacancies did increase significantly over the last eight years.

claim: "While (Charlie Crist) was governor, utility costs went up 30 percent and went from below the national average to above the national average. Since I got elected, utility rates have come down 11 percent and now we are below the average."
justification:
The claim made by Charlie Crist states that utility costs went up 30 percent during his governorship and then dropped 11 percent since Rick Scott took office, putting Florida below the national average again. However, the evidence provided indicates that this is not accurate.

Firstly, the data from the Florida Public Service Commission shows that electric rates for three out of four large investor-owned power companies in Florida peaked during Crist's administration in 2009. While there were increases in these rates, it was primarily due to large increases in fuel recovery costs rather than an increase in base rates, which are under the governor's control.

Secondly, the evidence shows that from 2007 to 2011, when Scott took office, the average monthly residential electric bill actually decreased slightly, not increased by 30 percent as claimed. The rate was higher during Crist's last year in office (11.18 cents per kilowatt hour) than it was in his first year (11.43 cents), contradicting the claim that utility costs went up significantly during his governorship.

Lastly, there has not been an 11 percent decrease in utility rates under Scott's tenure as claimed. In fact, the latest data available shows a slight increase of 5.6 percent since Scott took office, not a decrease. Furthermore, the evidence indicates that Florida was already above the national average in residential utility rates when Crist came into office and remained above the national average during his term, though by less than when he started.

Therefore, based on the evidence provided, it is appropriate to label the claim as false, as it does not align with the data on utility costs during Charlie Crist's governorship and the subsequent years under Rick Scott.

claim: "We have an 80 percent graduation rate in high school after spending more per student than any country in the world other than Liechtenstein, I think, or Luxembourg and a couple other small countries."
justification: The claim "We have an 80 percent graduation rate in high school after spending more per student than any country in the world other than Liechtenstein, I think, or Luxembourg and a couple other small countries" can be labeled as "True." This is because the evidence provided shows that Jeb Bush made this statement during a public event, and the article confirms his claim about the national high school graduation rate (81% according to the federal government's cohort method in 2012-13) and per-pupil spending compared to other countries. The spending figure provided ($12,731 per student on secondary education) is corroborated by a study conducted by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), which shows that four countries - Austria, Luxembourg, Norway, and Switzerland - spend more per student than the United States in secondary education. Therefore, Bush's claim about spending more per student than most countries, with the exception of a few small ones, is supported by the evidence.

claim: "All Aboard Florida is a 100 percent private venture. There is no state money involved."
justification:
The claim states that "All Aboard Florida is a 100 percent private venture. There is no state money involved." However, the evidence presented in the article clearly contradicts this assertion.

Firstly, the article points out that the Florida Legislature approved $10 million in "quiet zone" money for horns at railroad crossings which can be applied for by local government agencies for any rail crossing, not exclusively for those used by All Aboard Florida. This shows that state funds are being directly allocated towards infrastructure associated with All Aboard Florida.

Secondly, the article mentions that the Orlando International Airport is building an intermodal transportation facility where All Aboard Florida will be accommodated. Although All Aboard Florida will pay for its usage, the construction of this facility receives a loan and grant from the state. While it's stated that the airport will reimburse the state for the portion related to the rail connection, this still indicates that state funds are being used indirectly for All Aboard Florida.

Lastly, the article states that All Aboard Florida was initially proposed to use $44 million in state money to connect their trains to Tri-Rail, although this idea did not materialize and was officially shut down amid publicity. However, the fact that the proposal was made indicates a potential for state funding involvement.

Given these points of contention, it's clear that there is both federal and state money involved in All Aboard Florida, contradicting the initial claim that there is no state money involved. Therefore, the appropriate label for this claim would be "Conflicting".

claim: Says U.S. Rep. Connie Mack "took seven and a half years to finish college."
justification:
The claim "Says U.S. Rep. Connie Mack 'took seven and a half years to finish college'" receives the label "Conflicting" because there are conflicting reports about how long it took Mack to complete his education. On one hand, news articles have reported that Mack took seven or seven and a half years to finish college (as acknowledged by the statement). However, further investigation reveals that Mack actually attended Sante Fe Community College from spring 1986 to June 1988, which amounts to approximately two and a half years. He then transferred to the University of Florida in May 1988 and graduated with his bachelor's degree in advertising in May 1993, which is about five years later.

   The confusion arises from two factors. First, Mack was dual-enrolled in high school and college in the spring of 1986, overlapping technically with the time he enrolled in community college. Secondly, Mack took a two-year break from school (1991 and 1992) to work full-time. During this time, he finished his education through correspondence classes, earning his diploma in 1993.

   While the total duration from enrollment at Sante Fe Community College to graduation from the University of Florida appears to be seven and a half years, it is important to note that Mack was not actively pursuing his degree for this entire period due to the two-year break from school. Thus, the conflicting information in the claim stems from the fact that the total duration includes time when Mack was not enrolled in classes but still technically working towards his degree through correspondence courses. This ambiguity makes the claim "Conflicting."

claim: "One in six Texans don’t have health care. We’re the most uninsured state in the U.S."
justification: The claim that "One in six Texans don’t have health care. We’re the most uninsured state in the U.S." can be labeled as "True" based on the evidence provided. This is because the evidence demonstrates consistent data across various reliable sources, including the Census Bureau and the Kaiser Family Foundation, which all agree that Texas had the highest percentage of uninsured residents compared to other states in 2016. The exact percentage varies slightly among these sources (ranging from 15% to 16.6%), but they all indicate a rate of approximately one in six Texans lacking health insurance coverage. As such, it is accurate to state that Texas has the highest uninsured population and that one in six Texans do not have health insurance.

claim: Muslim nations did not "call out" the people who celebrated the 9/11 attacks.
justification: The claim that "Muslim nations did not 'call out' the people who celebrated the 9/11 attacks" has been labeled as "Conflicting." This is because the article provides evidence that contradicts both sides of the argument. On one hand, it acknowledges that there were instances of street celebrations in Muslim-majority countries following the 9/11 attacks (most notably in the Palestinian territories). However, it also shows that many official condemnations of the attacks were issued by governments and religious leaders of these same nations. Therefore, while it is true that no specific condemnation was made directly against those who celebrated the attacks, the overall reaction from Muslim nations was not one of unqualified approval or silence. This ambiguity makes the claim conflicting as it cannot be definitively labeled either true or false based on the evidence provided.

claim: "89,000 children were separated from their parents under Obama" and "only 1,900 children have been separated under Trump."
justification:
The claim that "89,000 children were separated from their parents under Obama" and "only 1,900 children have been separated under Trump" is labeled as False. This determination is appropriate because the evidence provided clearly states that immigrant family separations at the border during the Obama years did not happen at the scale that has occurred under Trump's "zero-tolerance" policy.

The article highlights that the 89,000 figure likely refers to a different set of children—children who arrived at the border alone, rather than those separated from their parents. Contrarily, the number of children separated from their parents under Trump's administration is unclear due to faulty record-keeping, but it is confirmed that this number is significantly lower than what was claimed in the original statement.

Furthermore, the article explains that family separations did not occur under the Obama administration as a result of a "zero-tolerance" policy like Trump's. Therefore, the claim is incorrect and can be categorized as False.

claim: "In Austin, Texas, the average homeowner is paying about $1,300 to $1,400 just for recapture," meaning funds spent in non-Austin school districts.
justification:
The claim that "In Austin, Texas, the average homeowner is paying about $1,300 to $1,400 just for recapture" is true, as supported by the article text. The evidence demonstrates that the Austin Independent School District (AISD) is one of the largest contributors to recapture payments in Texas, which are funds transferred from property-wealthier districts like Austin to less property-rich districts to equalize aid among school districts.

The article provides a breakdown of AISD's expected payment for recapture during the 2016-17 budget ($406 million), the percentage of this payment represented in their overall property taxes (38%), and the average taxable value of a home in the district ($328,844). Using these figures, it's calculated that the portion of taxes on an average-value residence that goes to recapture is $1,355.

Furthermore, experts consulted by the article confirm the calculation method used by AISD, making the claim more reliable and supported. In addition, the article also provides historical context of AISD's recapture payments, showing that they are projected to exceed $630 million in 2019, implying a significant ongoing burden on Austin homeowners for recapture payments.

Therefore, based on this evidence, it is accurate to label the claim as "True."

claim: If Florida expanded Medicaid, "some studies indicate it would create about 120,000 jobs."
justification: The claim "If Florida expanded Medicaid, it would create about 120,000 jobs" can be labeled as conflicting because there is evidence presented that supports both higher and lower job creation estimates. On one hand, the Florida Hospital Association's study commissioned by University of Florida researchers predicts approximately 120,000 jobs. However, other studies, such as those by Moody's and the White House Council of Economic Advisers, predict significantly fewer jobs – between 10,000 to 63,800 jobs over varying timeframes. The article also mentions that these lower estimates come from sources that do not have a specific position on the health care law or expansion. Furthermore, some experts questioned the precision and size of job predictions due to multiple concurrent policy changes, making it difficult to pinpoint an exact number of jobs created by Medicaid expansion. In light of this conflicting evidence, the claim cannot be definitively proven as true without more specific details or a consensus among experts regarding the exact number of jobs that would be created.

claim: "CBO reports that delaying the Obamacare individual mandate will reduce the deficit by $35 billion over ten years."
justification: The claim "CBO reports that delaying the Obamacare individual mandate will reduce the deficit by $35 billion over ten years" is labeled as "True". This is because the supporting article text clearly states that the information comes from a Congressional Budget Office (CBO) analysis, which determined that passing a bill that delays the start of the requirement for individuals to secure health insurance coverage and the associated tax penalties would save $35.4 billion over 10 years. The savings are primarily due to fewer uninsured Americans signing up for government health care programs or receiving federal subsidies, and more Americans receiving taxable income instead of non-taxable health insurance. While it's mentioned that there are costs associated with the delay (such as an increase in the number of people without health insurance), the article does not dispute the accuracy of the $35 billion savings figure over the 10-year period. Therefore, the claim is justified to be true based on the evidence provided.

claim: "Road congestion costs rush hour drivers in Austin and Dallas more than $1,000 a year. And in Houston, it’s even more -- almost $1,500 a year."
justification: The claim "Road congestion costs rush hour drivers in Austin and Dallas more than $1,000 a year. And in Houston, it’s even more -- almost $1,500 a year" is labeled as True. This label is appropriate because the evidence clearly demonstrates that this statement was made by Governor Greg Abbott, who based his claim on research conducted by the Texas A&M Transportation Institute. The Institute's calculations, which are detailed in the evidence text, show that for Houston, the total congestion cost per commuter was $1,490 in 2014. While there appears to be a slight discrepancy in the exact figures provided by the evidence and the claim (with the claim stating "almost" $1,500), it is important to note that the evidence shows the original claim made by Governor Abbott was closer to $1,500 rather than over $1,500. Therefore, the claim remains within the realm of truthfulness given the minor discrepancy and the substantial support from the research conducted by a reputable organization.

claim: "In 1916, the U.S. government predicted that by the 1940s all paper would come from hemp and that no more trees would need to be cut down."
justification: The claim that "In 1916, the U.S. government predicted that by the 1940s all paper would come from hemp and that no more trees would need to be cut down" is labeled as False. This determination is supported by the evidence which indicates that while there were documents in the U.S. Department of Agriculture archives about the potential use of hemp for paper production, these documents did not contain any such prediction or claim. The evidence further explains that these documents are highly technical and do not make any such sweeping predictions about the complete replacement of trees as a source of paper. In fact, the authors' powers of prediction in these documents were shown to be faulty as their prediction that "without doubt, hemp will continue to be one of the staple agricultural crops of the United States" did not come to pass. Therefore, it can be concluded that there is no verifiable evidence to support the claim that the U.S. government made such a prediction in 1916 about the production of all paper from hemp by the 1940s.

claim: Says that in 2008, President Barack Obama said normalization with Cuba would first require "liberation of all political prisoners and some basic steps toward freedom, including freedom of the press, political parties, labor unions."
justification:
The label "True" is appropriate because the article presents concrete and multiple instances where Senator Barack Obama (during his 2008 campaign) explicitly stated his conditions for normalizing relations with Cuba. These conditions included "liberation of all political prisoners," ensuring "freedom of the press," promoting "political parties," and granting "freedom of assembly." The evidence shows that Obama made these statements in various speeches, op-eds, and interviews, as well as during his presidential campaign.

For example, in an opinion piece written for the Miami Herald during the Democratic primary in 2007, Obama called for "unrestricted rights" for Cuban-American travel and remittances to the island and stated that he would use "aggressive and principled diplomacy" to promote democracy in Cuba. He also made it clear that normalizing relations with Cuba should be contingent upon progress towards these goals, including releasing political prisoners, promoting freedom of speech, assembly, and a free press, and holding fair elections.

Furthermore, in May 2008, Obama gave a speech in Miami where he reiterated his commitment to "libertad" (Spanish for freedom) and emphasized that the road to freedom for all Cubans must begin with justice for Cuba's political prisoners, the right of free speech, a free press, freedom of assembly, and free and fair elections. He also made it clear that he would be willing to meet with Cuban leaders "without preconditions" but only when there was progress towards these goals.

In summary, the evidence provided shows that Barack Obama, during his 2008 campaign, did indeed say that normalization with Cuba would first require "liberation of all political prisoners and some basic steps toward freedom, including freedom of the press, political parties, labor unions." This makes the claim "True".

claim: “If you have the Flu… get these two items… Sambucol (and) Oscillococcinum… in 48 hours you will feel better. In 72 hours you will be almost symptom-free.”
justification: The label of "Conflicting" is appropriate because while the claim suggests that both Sambucol and Oscillococcinum can effectively cure flu symptoms within 48-72 hours, the evidence presented indicates that there is ongoing debate within the medical community regarding their effectiveness. Although some small studies have shown positive results for Sambucol in relieving flu symptoms and shortening their duration, these findings are not universally accepted due to the limited number of participants involved. Furthermore, the claim that Oscillococcinum can considerably shorten the length of the flu is disputed by larger independent research organizations such as Cochrane, which have found no preventative effects or unbiased evidence supporting its effectiveness in treating flu symptoms. Additionally, both Sambucol and Oscillococcinum's websites acknowledge that their claims regarding influenza treatment "have not been evaluated by the Food and Drug Administration," further casting doubt on their efficacy as a cure for flu symptoms within such a short period. Thus, while the claim suggests quick and decisive results, the evidence provided highlights ongoing debate and a lack of definitive proof supporting these assertions.

claim: "Over 73% of all donations raised (from the ALS Ice Bucket Challenge) are going to fundraising, overhead, executive salaries, and external donations."
justification: The claim that ""Over 73% of all donations raised (from the ALS Ice Bucket Challenge) are going to fundraising, overhead, executive salaries, and external donations"" is given the label False because the evidence presented in the article indicates that this statement is incorrect. The article explains that the 73% figure comes from subtracting everything except for the 27% that falls under "research," which is misleading as it does not accurately represent the total spending of the ALS Association. The charitable way to view the post's error, according to the article, would be to say that "research accounts for only 27 percent of the ALS Association’s budget," but even this statement would still be misleading as the group's mission includes raising awareness, serving as a trusted source of information, providing patients with access to support services, and advocating for increased funding for research. If we include "patient and community services" and "public and professional education" as legitimate spending to advance the group’s stated mission, the percentage spent on items supporting those goals rises to nearly 79 percent. Therefore, the claim that most of the donations are being spent on non-ALS related expenses is not supported by the evidence provided in the article.

claim: Says Obama called Medicaid "broken" four years ago.
justification: The claim that "Says Obama called Medicaid 'broken' four years ago" is true as per the evidence presented. The text states that during a health-care discussion with Senate Democrats on June 2, 2009, President Barack Obama said, "We can't simply put more people into a broken system that doesn't work." Although Perry quoted these exact words in his speech at the Conservative Political Action Conference in 2013, the text provides context and confirms that these were indeed Obama's words from the 2009 meeting. Furthermore, the evidence further corroborates this by pointing out that Texas Gov. Rick Perry's spokesman confirmed that Perry was referring to this specific Obama speech in which he referred to Medicaid as "broken." Therefore, based on the evidence provided, it is accurate to say that Obama did call Medicaid 'broken' four years ago.

claim: Says he has "yet to get a response" from Barack Obama to his August 2010 letter making border security requests.
justification: The claim that "Says he has 'yet to get a response' from Barack Obama to his August 2010 letter making border security requests" is labeled as False because there is evidence that shows Governor Rick Perry received a response from John O. Brennan, assistant to the President for Homeland Security and Counterterrorism, on August 27, 2010. The response was made on White House letterhead, acknowledging Perry's concerns regarding border security and appreciating his outreach. Additionally, the evidence shows that the Obama administration had taken steps to address Perry's requests by signing the Southwest Border Security Act into law, which added resources such as National Guard troops along the border. Therefore, it is inaccurate for Perry to claim he has yet to receive a response from Barack Obama.

claim: Says President Dwight Eisenhower "moved 1.5 million illegal immigrants out of this country."
justification: The claim that "President Dwight Eisenhower moved 1.5 million illegal immigrants out of this country" is labeled as "Conflicting." This label is appropriate because the evidence provided indicates that there were significant deportations during Operation Wetback under President Eisenhower, but estimates on the exact number of people who were deported vary greatly, ranging from 250,000 to 1.3 million. The article suggests that the official apprehensions did not come close to the highest estimate, and there is evidence that a significant portion of those targeted for deportation self-deported or did not return to Mexico in large numbers. Therefore, while it is accurate to say that Eisenhower oversaw a campaign that resulted in many deportations, it is not supported by the evidence to claim that 1.5 million illegal immigrants were moved out of the country during this operation. Trump's statement can be seen as an exaggeration or a twist on the facts, and thus the label "Conflicting" is appropriate.

claim: Says Bill Nelson "cast the deciding vote for Obamacare cutting Medicare spending by $700 billion and letting an unelected board decide what gets covered here."
justification:
The label "Conflicting" is appropriate because while Bill Nelson did vote in favor of the bill that became Obamacare, the claim that he cast the "deciding vote" is not accurate and relies on political spin. The evidence indicates that Nelson was not one of the senators who held out until the last minute, as the Los Angeles Times reported, and thus his vote was not critical in passing the bill. However, the statement from American Crossroads suggests that Nelson's vote was decisive in the passage of Obamacare.

   Furthermore, the claim that the health care law cuts Medicare spending by $700 billion is a common talking point, but it requires careful interpretation to understand its accuracy. The CBO found that the health care law reduced Medicare outlays by $716 billion over ten years (from 2013 to 2022), but this is not the same as cutting a dollar amount from the Medicare program's budget each year or reducing benefits for Medicare beneficiaries.

   Finally, the claim that the health care law "lets an unelected board decide what gets covered here" oversimplifies the role of the Independent Payment Advisory Board (IPAB). While it is true that the IPAB can make recommendations to reduce Medicare costs, it is prohibited from rationing care or denying treatments to patients and cannot change who is eligible for Medicare or raise premiums for beneficiaries. Therefore, the claim that patients could find their benefits "rationed" or that the health care law allows the IPAB to make decisions about individual American's healthcare is exaggerated and misleading.

   In conclusion, while Bill Nelson did vote in favor of Obamacare, he did not cast the deciding vote as claimed by American Crossroads. The claim that the health care law cuts Medicare spending by $700 billion requires careful interpretation to understand its accuracy, and the claim that the health care law allows an unelected board to make decisions about individual American's healthcare is misleading. These claims are conflicting with the evidence presented.

claim: Says his tax plan wouldn't leave the federal government with a $1.1 trillion hole.
justification: The claim "Says his tax plan wouldn't leave the federal government with a $1.1 trillion hole" is labeled as False because the evidence demonstrates that Ben Carson's tax plan, as described in the article, would in fact result in a revenue shortfall. The plan's estimated revenue, based on a 15% flat income and corporate tax rate without deductions or loopholes, is found to be $2.6 trillion. However, government spending for 2015 is anticipated to be $3.7 trillion according to the Congressional Budget Office. This means that under Carson's proposed plan, there would still be a shortfall of $0.6 trillion in revenue compared to anticipated spending, and $1.1 trillion if we consider the current level of government spending. Therefore, based on the information provided, it is evident that Ben Carson's tax plan would indeed leave the federal government with a significant budgetary hole.

claim: Says in 2000, Fox News broke the story of George W. Bush’s drunk driving arrest. "Who broke it? Fox News."
justification: The label "Conflicting" is appropriate because the claim that Fox News broke the story of George W. Bush's drunk driving arrest in 2000 contradicts the evidence presented. In the article, it is clearly stated that Erin Fehlau from the local affiliate WPXT, not Fox News, was the one who found and initially reported the story. After confirming the information with the Bush campaign, Fox News then broadcasted the story, giving credit to WPXT for breaking it. Therefore, the claim is conflicting as it misrepresents the truth about who first uncovered the story.

claim: Says since Australia passed tough gun laws, "homicides by firearm have declined almost 60 percent."
justification:
The claim "Says since Australia passed tough gun laws, 'homicides by firearm have declined almost 60 percent'" is accurate due to the evidence provided in the article text. The evidence shows that after the passing of the tough gun laws following the Martin Bryant shootings in 1996, the number of gun homicides in Australia significantly decreased.

For instance, the number of gun homicides fell from 69 in 1996 (excluding the victims of the mass shooting) to 30 in 2012, which represents a decrease of 56.5 percent. Additionally, reputable researchers found that in the decade after the gun laws were implemented, firearm homicides dropped 59 percent. This substantial drop supports the claim that homicides by firearm have declined almost 60 percent since Australia passed tough gun laws.

While the evidence suggests that the decrease in gun homicides is likely due to the new gun laws, it's acknowledged that further research and analysis are necessary to definitively establish the causal relationship between the laws and the decline in gun violence. However, the evidence provided strongly supports the claim that gun homicides have decreased significantly since Australia passed tough gun laws.

claim: Says under President Barack Obama, the United States has created "five million jobs."
justification: The claim that "Says under President Barack Obama, the United States has created 'five million jobs'" is given the label of "Conflicting" because the evidence provided indicates that while it is technically accurate to say that there was a net increase of approximately 5 million private-sector jobs during Obama's presidency, this increase only occurred over a specific time frame (February 2010 to October 2012). The article explains that when considering the entirety of Obama's term in office, job growth was less than the claimed figure due to losses in the public sector. Therefore, the claim is accurate within certain parameters, but it does not reflect the full picture of job growth during Obama's presidency. This makes the claim somewhat misleading, as it gives the impression that job growth was consistently strong throughout his term when this was not always the case.

claim: "If you take into account all the people who are struggling for work, or have just stopped looking, the real unemployment rate is over 15 percent."
justification: The claim "If you take into account all the people who are struggling for work, or have just stopped looking, the real unemployment rate is over 15 percent" can be deemed as True according to the provided evidence. The evidence demonstrates that the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) offers an alternative measure of labor underutilization known as U-6, which calculates unemployment by including three groups: unemployed, marginally attached to the labor force, and working part-time for economic reasons. In January 2012, the U-6 rate was 15.1 percent, supporting the claim that the real unemployment rate is over 15 percent when considering these additional categories of people. Furthermore, the article notes that Romney's statement is an improvement from his previous phrasing in the Tampa debate, where he did not explicitly reference the broader U-6 methodology. Therefore, Romney's claim is accurate based on this definition and data provided by BLS.

claim: "Four times, I said, he (John McCain)is a hero, but you know ... people choose selective pieces."
justification: The label "Conflicting" is appropriate because Donald Trump's statements about John McCain being a hero exhibit inconsistency and contradiction. In one instance, Trump stated that McCain "is not a war hero," while in another, he said five times, "He (McCain) is a war hero." However, the context of these statements reveals that Trump qualifies his praise with conditions such as McCain being captured or implies that being a war hero doesn't mean anything special if one gets captured. These additions to his statements about McCain undermine his initial assertion that McCain is a hero, creating an apparent conflict in his position. Furthermore, experts quoted in the article suggest that Trump's qualifications significantly change the meaning of his sentence, implying that he does not view McCain as an exceptional war hero due to his capture. This inconsistency and contradiction in Trump's statements regarding McCain's status as a hero justify labeling them as "Conflicting."

claim: "Last year, we had zero percent growth in GDP in Virginia ...The only states that did worse than us were Alaska and Mississippi."
justification: The claim that "Last year, we had zero percent growth in GDP in Virginia ...The only states that did worse than us were Alaska and Mississippi" can be labeled as True, based on the evidence provided in the supporting article text. According to the article, a spokesman for Glen Sturtevant's campaign confirmed that the information came from a June article in The Washington Post about preliminary state gross domestic product figures for 2014 released by the Bureau of Economic Analysis at the U.S. Department of Commerce. The article states that Virginia's GDP of about $427 billion last year was indeed flat, with zero percent inflation-adjusted growth from 2013. Only two states, Mississippi and Alaska, trailed Virginia in growth, with their state economies shrinking. Therefore, the statement made by Glen Sturtevant is supported by the data from a reliable source, the Bureau of Economic Analysis, making it true.

claim: Says Pat McCrory "shepherded in driver’s licenses for illegal aliens in the aftermath of the 9/11 terrorist attacks."
justification: Justification: The label "Conflicting" is appropriate for the claim that "Pat McCrory shepherded in driver’s licenses for illegal aliens in the aftermath of the 9/11 terrorist attacks." This is because the provided evidence clearly demonstrates that while it's true that DACA recipients (a subset of illegal immigrants) became eligible for driver's licenses during McCrory's term, he opposed this expansion and was only following a court ruling at that time. Therefore, McCrory did not actively "shepherd in" the policy change as stated in the claim. Furthermore, the evidence also reveals that McCrory was the only Republican governor since 9/11, but the policy change under discussion occurred in response to 9/11, which was over a decade after the terrorist attacks. This additional detail further supports the label "Conflicting" as it indicates a misrepresentation of the timeline and McCrory's role in the policy change.

claim: The Obama administration spent "$205,075 in ‘stimulus’ funds to relocate a shrub that sells for $16."
justification: The label "Conflicting" is appropriate because the claim made in the original statement that "$205,075 in ‘stimulus’ funds were spent to relocate a shrub that sells for $16" is not entirely accurate based on the information presented in the supporting article text. While it is true that the shrub was moved using stimulus funds as part of a road project, and that its commercial equivalent can be purchased for under $20, the article clearly states that the actual cost of translocating the specific wild Franciscan manzanita was funded by local tolls and not directly from the stimulus package. The confusion may arise because the overall project, which included the shrub relocation, received stimulus funds, but the specific cost of moving the rare plant is not accurately represented in the original claim.

claim: "Charlie Crist allowed college tuition to increase up to 15 percent every year."
justification: Justification: The claim "Charlie Crist allowed college tuition to increase up to 15 percent every year" is true as supported by the provided article text. According to the evidence, it was stated that before Governor Charlie Crist took office in 2007, there was no cap on how much the price of undergraduate tuition could go up. In 2009, the Legislature allowed the largest state research universities to raise rates up to 15 percent per year. Furthermore, the evidence explains that during Crist's governorship, the Legislature increased college tuition by 6 percent in 2008 and 8 percent in 2009, with the total increase reaching 15 percent for those years. Although Governor Crist initially opposed raising tuition in 2007, he later reversed his decision and the 5 percent hike took effect. Additionally, it was stated that the Legislature approved a new plan in 2009, allowing the Board of Governors to raise undergraduate tuition rates past whatever the Legislature approved as long as the total increase didn't exceed 15 percent per year. This evidence demonstrates that Crist allowed college tuition to increase up to 15 percent every year during his tenure as Governor.

claim: Says that in 2001, Rick Perry spoke favorably of binational health insurance between Mexico and Texas.
justification: The claim that "in 2001, Rick Perry spoke favorably of binational health insurance between Mexico and Texas" is labeled as conflicting because while it is true that Perry mentioned the concept in a speech during an August 2001 summit on border issues, the speech also indicates that he supported a study to assess the feasibility of such insurance, not that he spoke in favor of its implementation. The study ultimately found numerous barriers to accomplishing binational health insurance and no further action was taken. Therefore, while Perry did discuss the idea, it is unclear from the evidence provided whether he advocated for its immediate adoption or merely supported a study to explore its potential viability. The conflicting nature of this claim lies in the ambiguity surrounding Rick Perry's stance on binational health insurance following his speech in 2001.

claim: "If you have a job in this country, (there's a) 97 percent chance that you're not going to be in poverty."
justification: The claim "If you have a job in this country, (there's a) 97 percent chance that you're not going to be in poverty" can be considered True according to the evidence provided. The evidence supports this by citing data from the Census Bureau for the year 2012, which shows that 2.9% of Americans between 18 and 64 who worked full-time, year-round were in poverty. This percentage is significantly lower than the poverty rate for the general population, indicating a strong correlation between employment and decreased poverty levels. However, it should be noted that the evidence does acknowledge that the claim might not be exactly 97%, but closer to 93%. Nonetheless, this slight deviation from the exact figure does not disprove the overall validity of the claim, as it still suggests a very high probability of avoiding poverty with full-time employment.

claim: "We, the bishops of the United States -- can you believe it -- in 1919 came out for more affordable, more comprehensive, more universal health care."
justification: The claim "We, the bishops of the United States -- can you believe it -- in 1919 came out for more affordable, more comprehensive, more universal health care" is true because the evidence clearly states that the National Catholic Welfare Council, the predecessor of the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops, held a meeting in February 1919 where a group of bishops led by Father John A. Ryan published the "Bishops’ Program of Social Reconstruction." This guide advocated for comprehensive provision for insurance against illness, invalidity, unemployment, and old age, which can be interpreted as a call for more affordable, comprehensive, and universal health care. Furthermore, it is mentioned that the group has publicly supported various proposals, including former President Bill Clinton’s health care plan in 1993, further demonstrating their support for universal health care initiatives over the years.

claim: "One-half of undocumented workers pay federal income taxes, which means they are paying more federal income taxes than Donald Trump pays."
justification: Justification: The claim "One-half of undocumented workers pay federal income taxes, which means they are paying more federal income taxes than Donald Trump pays" is labeled as conflicting because while it is supported by educated estimates and expert opinions regarding the number of undocumented workers who contribute to federal income taxes (ITIN filers, Social Security contributions, etc.), there is no official data or confirmation that exactly half of all undocumented workers are currently paying federal income taxes.
